column1: Puyallup ( (listen) pew-AL-əp or  pew-AWL-əp) is a city in Pierce County
column2: Washington
column3: United States
column4: located about 10 miles (16 km) southeast of Tacoma and 35 miles (56 km) south of Seattle. It had a population of 37
column6: with the Washington State Office of Financial Management estimating an increase to 42
column7: 361 as of 2019. The city's name comes from the Puyallup Tribe of Native Americans and means "the generous people". Puyallup is also home to the Washington State Fair

column1: The Puyallup Valley was originally inhabited by the Puyallup people
column2: known in their language as the spuyaləpabš
column3: meaning "generous and welcoming behavior to all people (friends and strangers) who enter our lands." The first white settlers in the region were part of the first wagon train to cross the Cascade Range at Naches Pass in 1853.Native Americans numbered about 2
column4: 000 in what is now the Puyallup Valley in the 1830s and 1840s. The first European settlers arrived in the 1850s. In 1877
column5: Ezra Meeker platted a townsite and named it Puyallup after the local Puyallup Indian tribes
column6: 11 years after departing from Indiana. The town grew rapidly throughout the 1880s
column7: in large part thanks to Meeker's hop farm
column8: which brought in millions of dollars to Puyallup
column9: leading to it eventually being incorporated in 1890
column10: with Ezra Meeker as its first mayor. The turn of the 20th century brought change to the valley with the growth of nearby Tacoma and the interurban rail lines. The Western Washington Fairgrounds were developed giving local farmers a place to exhibit their crops and livestock. During the early part of World War II
column11: the fairgrounds were part of Camp Harmony
column12: a temporary Japanese American internment camp for more than 7
column14: most of whom were American citizens. Subsequently
column15: they were moved to the Minidoka relocation center near Twin Falls

column1: Downtown and the valley neighborhoods of Puyallup would likely be damaged or destroyed in a moderate or large eruption of nearby Mount Rainier.
Puyallup experiences an oceanic climate (Köppen classification: Csb; Trewartha classification: Do). Winters are cool and wet
column2: with high temperatures averaging in the mid to upper 40s and lows near freezing. The surrounding hills (averaging 500 feet (150 m) above sea level) often experience the extremes of winter
column3: with more frequent lows below freezing and greater snowfall. Snowfall is rare
column4: and often only occurs on a few days a year
column6: and as late as April. Spring brings less rain and milder temperatures
column7: with highs regularly in the mid 50s (12–14 °C)
column8: to around 60 (15 °C). Spring often records the first 70 °F (21 °C) temperature. Summers are warm and dry
column9: with highs in the 70s most days. Many days can max out in the 80s
column10: and occasionally the 90s. Readings above 100 °F (37.7 °C) are very rare; on July 29
column12: during a prolonged period of hot weather
column14: the warmest since records have been kept. Summer thunderstorms happen occasionally
column15: but are often isolated and rarely (if ever) severe. Storms often roll off the Cascades and into the surrounding areas; they are usually a result of warm moist air from monsoons in the southwestern United States. Summer is warmest in July and August
column16: and occasionally September. By October and the fall season
column17: temperatures start to drop and precipitation increases.

column1: The valley in which Puyallup was originally settled forms the town. Its fertile soil is optimal for the acres of daffodils which were grown for distribution worldwide
column2: and are featured in the town's annual spring parade. The Puyallup River meanders between the hills
column3: through the glacial basin
column4: from its namesake glacier on Mt. Rainier
column5: terminating in Puget Sound at the Port of Tacoma. It is cold
column8: sometimes green. From most perspectives in the town of Puyallup
column9: Mt. Rainier is visible to the southeast.

column1: Downtown Puyallup has several notable landmarks
column2: including Ezra Meeker's mansion
column3: which was built and inhabited by one of the town's founding families
column4: who made their way to Puyallup via the Oregon trail. The downtown shopping district is made up of historic buildings
column5: which date to the town's origin. Pioneer Park is a community focal point
column8: and walking paths. As the focal point of the park
column9: there is a bronze statue honoring Ezra Meeker. A new element is the public stage by the public library. At the public stage local musicians put on free shows for the public. Southeast Puyallup is also where the Pierce County Foothills Trail begins.

column1: The Ezra Meeker Mansion is an Italianate Victorian building completed around 1890
column2: which was the home of Oregon Trail pioneer Ezra Meeker and his wife Eliza Jane. Known as the “Hop King”
column3: Meeker ultimately lost a fortune due to a disease in the hops. He became well known for tracking the Oregon Trail over the years and erecting monuments along its course in an effort to memorialize it. The mansion functions today as a small house museum owned and operated by the Puyallup Historical Society at Meeker Mansion (formerly the Ezra Meeker Historical Society). The building can also be rented out for weddings

column1: Puyallup is home to the Washington State Fair. It is one of the ten largest U.S. state fairs
column2: attracting over one million people each year. The city itself is built around the Puyallup Fairgrounds
column3: which can be seen prominently from neighboring South Hill. The fair traditionally runs for 21 days in September; there is also a "Spring Fair" which takes place for four days in April. The fair serves as an anchor for local businesses and restaurants. Previously named the "Puyallup Fair"
column4: it received its current name in 2013. "Do the Puyallup" has been its long-standing promotional slogan.

column2: the Puyallup Fairgrounds became the Puyallup Assembly Area (euphemistically referred to as "Camp Harmony") and were used as an internment camp for United States citizens or residents of Japanese descent or origin.

column1: Puyallup also hosts and is origin of the annual four-part Daffodil Parade
column2: which takes place every year in Tacoma
column3: Puyallup

column1: The parade includes many groups and has many floats
column2: most of which are covered in daffodils
column3: or are themed in the daffodil season. Most of the local junior high and high school marching bands also march. Car clubs
column4: veteran groups and also some businesses are a part of the parade.

column1: Puyallup is known for its myriad antiques stores
column2: many of which are located next to each other on the main north-south street of Meridian. Puyallup is one of many cities and towns in Washington that contains an 'old-fashioned' downtown shopping area.

column1: The Karshner Museum is the only K–12 teaching museum owned and operated by a school district west of the Mississippi. The essential education and curriculum-based program serves the Puyallup School District's 20
column2: 000 K–12 student population. Since 1930
column3: the Karshner Museum has provided hands-on and curriculum-based learning experiences to thousands of students through the museum visit program. The education trunk or "Discovery Kit" program has served students
column4: teachers and community members since the 1970s. These Kits utilize real or replica artifacts for the purposes of bringing history
column5: art and culture to life in the school classroom.

column2: the regional nonprofit organization Valley Arts United began working with local volunteers to support a rotating selection of outdoor public artwork. Consisting mostly of statuary dispersed about the downtown core
column3: this collection has grown to a collection of about 32 permanent pieces. New works are added regularly.

column1: The Puyallup Main Street Association produces the Puyallup Farmers' Market each year. The market is open Saturdays (9 a.m. to 2 p.m.) from mid-April to mid-October
column2: with a Holiday Market in December (together with the lighted Santa Parade – first Saturday of December). Puyallup Farmers' Market is the largest market in Pierce County and one of the largest in the state. Thousands of people come each week to purchase produce
column3: plants and seeds
column9: and more. Free live entertainment. The market fills Pioneer Park and the modern pavilion building
column10: and takes over Elm and 4th streets.

column1: The Puyallup School District has over 30 schools attended by more than 20
column2: 000 students. The district is the ninth largest in Washington state
column3: extending to neighboring South Hill
column5: and the Edgewood area. Some local schools hold annual warning drills on account of the dangers of lahars in the event of an eruption of Mount Rainier
column6: which would leave students with a maximum of 15 minutes to find higher land or the top of a building.Puyallup is also home to Pierce College Puyallup
column7: a community college that opened in 1990. It is one of the two main campuses belonging to the college
column8: the other being Pierce College Fort Steilacoom in Lakewood.

column1: The city is served by the Puyallup Public Library
column2: which was established in 1913 and has been housed in its current building in Pioneer Park since 2002. It is not affiliated with either the Tacoma Public Library or the Pierce County Library System.

column1: The Herald is the local newspaper for eastern Pierce County. It is published once a week on Wednesdays.  The paper is distributed by The News Tribune.
Puyallup is located at the intersection of State Route 167 and State Route 512
column2: with freeway access to Lakewood and the Green River Valley. The city is also served by Pierce Transit buses and Sounder commuter rail at Puyallup station.

column1: The city is located near the Pierce County Airport (KPLU)
column2: a small municipal airport in South Hill.
